sentences.sentence: I divided the guns between us.
We entered the forest, with all possible care and silence, and marched till we came to the edge of the forest next to the natives.
Here I called softly to Friday, and I told him to go closer, and tell me if he could see there plainly what they were doing.
He did so, and came immediately back and told me they were eating the flesh of one of their prisoners, and were preparing to eat another.
He told me it was not one of their tribe( 部落 ), but one of the white men he had told me of.
I was filled with horror( 恐惧 ) at the very naming of the white man, and going to a tree, I saw plainly a white man.
He lay upon the beach, with his hands and his feet tied.
I held back my anger, though I was indeed quite furious( 狂怒的 ), and got behind some bushes. From here I had a full view of( 清楚地看见 ) them at the distance of about eighty yards.
I had now not a moment to lose, for nineteen of the natives had just sent another two to butcher( 屠杀 ) the poor Christian.
I turned to Friday. “Now, Friday,” said I, “do exactly as you see me do.” So with the other gun I  took my aim at( 瞄准 ) the natives, telling him to do the same.
Then asking him if he was ready, he replied, “Yes.” “Then fire at them,” said I, and at the same moment I fired also.
Friday took his aim( 瞄准 ) so much better than I, that on the side that he shot he killed two of them, and wounded three more.
On my side, I killed one and wounded two.
All of them that were not hurt, jumped upon their feet, but did not immediately know which way to run, or which way to look.
As soon as the first shot was made, I threw down that gun, and took up a bird gun, and Friday did the same.
“Are you ready, Friday?” said I. “Yes,” said he.
“Fire, then,” said I, “in the name of God;”
and with that I fired again among the amazed( 吃惊的 ) natives, and so did Friday.
We saw only two drop, but so many were wounded, that they ran about yelling( 大叫 ) and screaming like mad creatures.
They were all bloody, and most of them terribly wounded. Three more fell quickly, injured though not quite dead.
“Now, Friday,” said I, taking up another of the guns, “follow me.”
Upon this I rushed out of the forest and showed myself, with Friday close to me.
Running as fast as I could, I headed directly towards the poor victim lying upon the beach.
The two men who were just going to kill him had fled( 逃跑 ) to the shore.
They had jumped into a boat, and three more of the rest went the same way.
I turned to Friday, and he understood me immediately, and shot at them.
He killed two of them, and wounded a third, who lay down in the bottom of the boat as if dead.
While my man Friday fired at them, I pulled out my knife, and cut the ropes that bound( 捆 ) the poor victim.
I lifted him up, and then asked him what country he was from. He said “Espagnole( 西班牙 )”;

“Seignior( 先生 ),” said I, with as much Spanish as I could put together, “we will talk afterwards( 以后 ), but we must fight now. If you have any strength left, take this gun and sword, and join the fight.”
He took them very thankfully, and attacked those who wanted to kill him with great anger, and had cut two of them in pieces in an instant( 顷刻间 ).
Friday meanwhile was chasing( 追赶 ) the fleeing( 逃跑的 ) natives, and killed some of them, but a few others were too quick for him.
The full account of what occurred is as follows:—
Three killed at our first shot from the tree; two killed at the next shot; two killed by Friday in the boat; two killed by Friday of those at first wounded;

one killed by Friday in the wood; three killed by the Spaniard( 西班牙人 ); four dead from their wounds, or killed by Friday in his chase( 追逐 ) of them; four escaped in the boat, one of which was wounded—twenty-one in all.
Those that were in the boat worked hard to get out of range( 射程 ) of our guns, and though Friday made two or three shots at them, I do not think that he hit any of them.
Friday would have chased( 追赶 ) them.
Indeed, I was very anxious to prevent them from carrying news home to their people, for fear they should come back perhaps with two or three hundred boats.
So I agreed to chase( 追逐 ) them by sea, but when I reached the boat I was surprised to find another poor native lying there.
His hands and feet were tied, and he was almost dead with fear.
I immediately cut the ropes with which they had tied him.
When Friday came to him, I told him to speak to this man, but when Friday saw his face, he began to sing and jump about.
It was a long while before I could make him tell me what was the matter, but when he calmed down a little, he told me that it was his father.
Friday sat down by his father, and held his father’s head for many minutes.
Then he took his father’s arms and ankles( 脚踝 ), which were numbed( 麻木 ) and tight( 拉紧的 ) from the ropes, and rubbed( 揉 ) them with his hands.
This event put an end to our plans of a chase( 追逐 ).
I had in my pocket two or three bunches( 束 ) of raisins( 葡萄干 ), so I gave Friday a handful of them for his father.
He had no sooner given his father these raisins( 葡萄干 ), than I saw him get out of the boat.
Friday ran away as if he had gone mad, and in a quarter of an hour I saw him come back again with a pot of fresh water.
When his father had drunk, I called to him to ask if there was any water left.
He said, “Yes”; and I had him give it to the poor Spaniard( 西班牙人 ), who was indeed very weak.
Then I told Friday to help the Spaniard( 西班牙人 ) up if he could, but Friday took the Spaniard( 西班牙人 ) upon his back, and carried him away to the boat with his father.
He then pushed the boat off, and paddled( 划桨 ) it along the shore faster than I could walk, and brought them both safe to the stream beside my house.
Leaving them in the boat, he ran away to fetch the other boat.
As soon as I had made sure my two weak, rescued prisoners were safe, and given them shelter( 住所 ), I began to think of making some food for them.
I ordered Friday to kill a young goat, and made them a very good meal of meat and soup.
After we had eaten, I then began to enter into a little conversation with my two new subjects( 对象 ).
I told Friday to ask his father what he thought of the escape of the natives in that boat.
I was particularly curious whether we might expect them to return, with a power too great for us to resist( 反抗 ).
His opinion was that they were so terribly frightened by our guns, that he believed they would tell the people they were all killed by thunder and lightning, not by men.
This, he said, he knew because he heard them all cry out so.
As I came to hear much later, those natives never tried to return to the island.
They believed whoever went to that island would be destroyed with fire from the gods.

article_info.previous: 昨天我们读到Robinson和星期五相处愉快，并教会他使用英语。在同星期五的交谈中，Robinson发现他可以通过星期五的帮助离开这个小岛。后来，岛上来了大约二十个土著人。他们准备杀死三名囚犯，并吃他们的肉。于是，Robinson和星期五武装好，准备和他们来一场大战。
article_info.share_words: I divided the guns between us. We entered the forest, with all possible care and silence, and marched till we came to the edge of the forest next to the natives.

question.en: Were there any white men kept as prisoners?

analysis: 文中说：“I saw plainly a white man. He lay upon the beach, with his hands and his feet tied.” 所以选A。

question.cn: 当Robinson知道那些土著要吃那个白人，他做了什么？
question.en: When Robinson knew that the natives were going to eat the white man, what did he do?

options.en: He turned back and ran away.

options.cn: 他朝着土著人开枪，并让星期五也这样做。
options.en: He fired at the natives and told Friday to do the same.

options.cn: 他直接冲向那些土著人。
options.en: He rushed towards the natives directly.

analysis: 文中说：“So with the other gun I took my aim at the natives, telling him to do the same. Then asking him if he was ready, he replied, “Yes.” “Then fire at them,” said I, and at the same moment I fired also.”所以选B。
文中说：“I lifted him up, and then asked him what country he was from. He said ‘Espagnole’”所以选B。

question.cn: 在船里发现的可怜的土著人是谁？
question.en: Who was the poor native found in the boat?

analysis: 文中说：“But when he calmed down a little, he told me that it was his father.”所以选B。

question.cn: 为什么那些土著人不会再回来了？
question.en: Why wouldn’t the natives come back to the island?

options.en: Because they were so frightened by the guns.
Because they were so frightened by Friday.

analysis: 文中说：“His opinion was that they were so terribly frightened by our guns, that he believed they would tell the people they were all killed by thunder and lightning, not by men. ”所以选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第60天
